repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This PR adds several interactive capabilities to a confirmation buffer.

### LSP code actions

Didn't intend to add them, but was curious to see how it fits in the overall "in-process LSP server" approach. This can also serve as a future reference of code actions for in-process LSP servers.

Currently implemented actions are (act on "plugin at cursor"):
  - "Update" and "Skip updating" (if has updates). The idea is the use case of looking at changelog and not wanting to update right away some plugins. So instead of "Yank hash(es), update `version` in 'init.lua', restart, `vim.pack.update()`, and possibly revert 'init.lua' updates" use code action.
  - "Delete". The idea is seeing a plugin that user forgot to delete. Instead of "yank plugin name and `:lua vim.pack.delete({ '<C-r>0' })<CR>` use code action.

After applying code action, plugin's section is removed from the update, so `:write` only acts on the left plugins.

### Jump to next/previous plugin section

Map locally to 'nvim-pack' buffer the `[[` and `]]` to jump to next/previous plugin section.

---

Here is a demo:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ee426ea6-5687-46f6-8b27-f7527f135a6d

---

Resolve #34773

comment_data.body: why is double-underscore used here? single underscore means "private don't use". there is no other "super private" variation...

-      { 'fetch', '--quiet', '--tags', '--force', '--recurse-submodules=yes', 'origin' },
-      p.path
-    )
+    if not opts.__offline then

comment_data.body:
the doc seems to imply this name:


```suggestion
local function get_confirm_update_plugins(bufnr)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -822,6 +822,31 @@ local function show_confirm_buf(lines, on_finish)
   vim.lsp.buf_attach_client(bufnr, require('vim.pack._lsp').client_id)
 end
 
+--- Get map of plugin names that need update: all plugin sections present in
+--- confirmation buffer under "# Update" section.
+--- @param bufnr integer
+--- @return table<string,boolean>
+local function get_confirmed_update_plugins(bufnr)

@@ -22,6 +23,48 @@ local get_confirm_bufnr = function(uri)
   return tonumber(uri:match('^nvim%-pack://(%d+)/confirm%-update$'))
 end
 
+local GROUP_HEADER_PATTERN = '^# (%S+)'
+local PLUGIN_HEADER_PATTERN = '^## (.+)$'

comment_data.body:
It's just that using (what looks like) three verbs in a row throws me off.
Probably something like `get_update_map()` is better here.

comment_data.body: There are cases of using double-underscore to mean "super private" and I remember to have seen that in Matrix discussions. Using single underscore is indeed easier, I agree.

comment_data.body:
> There are cases of using double-underscore to mean "super private" and I remember to have seen that in Matrix discussions.

It was discussed but we decided against it. `__` is for Lua-internal stuff, and we don't have a clear use-case for using both single-underscore and double-underscore for Nvim stuff.

-      p.path
-    )

comment_data.body: Generally should not mention implementation details in the docs. Besides being irrelevant to most users, it also can constrain us to a particular approach.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -364,14 +364,19 @@ update({names}, {opts})                                    *vim.pack.update()*
     • Depending on `force`:
       • If `false`, show confirmation buffer. It lists data about all set to
         update plugins. Pending changes starting with `>` will be applied
-        while the ones starting with `<` will be reverted. It has special
-        in-process LSP server attached to provide more interactive features.
-        Currently supported methods:
+        while the ones starting with `<` will be reverted. It has dedicated
+        buffer-local mappings:
+        • |]]| and |[[| to navigate through plugin sections.
+        It has special in-process LSP server attached to provide more
+        interactive features. Currently supported methods:

comment_data.body:
What part do you mean as implementation detail here? The goal of this is to describe to users what extra interactive actions/features are available inside confirmation buffer. Those are:
- `[[` / `]]` navigate through plugin headers and not the built-in notion of `:h section`.
- There is in-process LSP server with certain set of features. Mentioning LSP is important because it allows users to be aware that their custom LSP mappings for document symbols, hover, and code actions do work here.

Do you suggest mention nothing at all? Or Leave currently supported methods of in-process LSP?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

-        while the ones starting with `<` will be reverted. It has special

-        Currently supported methods:

+        interactive features. Currently supported methods:

comment_regular_data.body:
> * Update" and "Skip updating" (if has updates). ... instead of "Yank hash(es), update `version` in 'init.lua' ... use code action.
> * "Delete". ... Instead of "yank plugin name and `:lua vim.pack.delete({ '<C-r>0' })<CR>` use code action.

Unless these update init.lua, this is unlikely to see much usage. Managing plugins for 1 session is a pretty niche thing for users to do.

I guess it could become more relevant if we support `pkg.json` or some other way to define the user's plugins instead of inlining in init.lua

> Unless these update init.lua, this is unlikely to see much usage. Managing plugins for 1 session is a pretty niche thing for users to do.

Selective update and skip update do not have 1 session effect. They last until the next `vim.pack.update()`.

Here are the use cases that I see pretty useful and not niche:
- Skip update:
    - Run `vim.pack.update()` and inspect changelogs.
    - See that some 'pluginA' has breaking change.
    - Decide that there is no time to deal with that right now. Press `gra` and choose "Skip updating". Execute `:write` to update everything else.
    - Keep using Neovim without breaking changes until the next `vim.pack.update()`, which will fetch new changes and show again that there are (not applied from earlier) breaking changes. Whether to apply them, skip again, or freeze plugin is up to the user.
- Update single plugin has the similar use as previous one, but if user wants to be more in control after reading changelogs.
- Delete plugin:
    - Remove plugin spec from `vim.pack.add()` call in 'init.lua', but forget to `vim.pack.del()` it.
    - After running `vim.pack.update()` the plugin will be present in the confirmation buffer. Note that with no arguments It is not visible *yet*, but it will be after there is a persistent plugin spec storage (part of #34776). Visible unwanted plugin serves as a reminder to delete it, which can be done via `gra` and choosing "Delete".

The "skip updating single plugin" is the most useful use case here. After it is present as a code action, adding other two are pretty low cost.

---

Besides actual plugin manager use cases, the following are maybe even as important:
- This requires no new API, no new UI, no new concepts. It adds "actions at cursor" in a way that is both established and already known how to customize by the user.
- This promotes the idea of in-process LSP that can actually do stuff. I *really* think that this might have a positive long-term effect on the whole Neovim plugin ecosystem, as it showcases a more uniform way of creating interactive features.

repo.name: neovim

title: Make interactive update more interactive
